Perform the intensity analysis from a cross-tabulation matrices

Source: R/intensityFunction.R
intensityanalysis.Rd

This function inplement the Intensity Analysis, a quantitative method to analyze maps of land categories from several points in time for a single site by considering cross-tabulation matrices, where one matrix summarizes the change in each time interval.

intensityanalysis(dataset, class_n, class_m, area_km2 = TRUE)

Arguments

dataset

The list of object from contingenceTable.
class_n

character. the gaining category in the transition of interest n.
class_m

character. the losing category in the transition of interest m.
area_km2

logical. Whether the change would be computed in km2 or quantity of pixel unit.

Value

Intensity objects including the levels tables and strationarity test tables

Details

There are three levels of analysis, starting from general to more detailed levels, where each level exposes different types of information given the previous level of analysis (Aldwaik and Pontius, 2012, 2013).

  1. The interval level examines how the size and speed of change vary across time intervals.

  2. The category level examines how the size and intensity of gross losses and gross gains in each category vary across categories for each time interval.

  3. The transition level examines how the size and intensity of a category’s transitions vary across the other categories that are available for that transition.

At each level, the method tests for stationarity of patterns across time intervals.

The function return a list with 10 objects:

  • lulc_table: A tibble of contingency between all step of time analysed, contains 6 columns:

    1. Period: <fct>. The period of change in the format first year - last year.

    2. From: <fct>. The class in the first year.

    3. To: <fct>. The class in the last year.

    4. km2: dbl. The quantity in kilometer that transit from the classes From to To in the period.

    5. Interval: dbl. The number of time point between the first and the last year of the period.

    6. QtPixel: int. The quantity in number of pixel that transits from the classes From to To in the period.

  • lv1_tbl: An "IntensityL01" object containing 1 table with 4 columns:

    1. Period: <fct>. The period [Yt, Yt+1].

    2. PercentChange: <dbl>. Interval Change Area (percent of map).

    3. St: <dbl>. annual intensity of change for time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

    4. U: <dbl>. value of uniform line for time intensity analysis.

  • lv2_gain: An "IntensityL02" object containing a slot with lookup table af the colors associate with the land classes and a table with 6 columns:

    1. Period: <fct>. The period [Yt, Yt+1].

    2. To: <fct>. a category j.

    3. Interval: <dbl>. duration of the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    4. GG_km2/GG_pixel: <dbl>/<int>. area of gross gain of category j during [Yt, Yt+1].

    5. Gtj: <dbl>. annual intensity of gross gain of category j for time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

    6. St: <dbl>. annual intensity of change for time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

  • lv2_loss: An "IntensityL02" object containing a slot with lookup table af the colors associate with the land classes and a table with 6 columns:

    1. Period: <fct>. The period [Yt, Yt+1].

    2. From: <fct>. a category i.

    3. Interval: <dbl>. duration of the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    4. GG_km2/GG_pixel: <dbl>/<int>. area of gross loss of category j during [Yt, Yt+1].

    5. Lti: <dbl>. annual intensity of gross loss of category i for time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

    6. STt: <dbl>. annual intensity of change for time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

  • gain_n: An "IntensityL03" object containing a slot with lookup table af the colors associate with the land classes and a table with 7 columns:

    1. Period: <fct>. The period [Yt, Yt+1].

    2. From: <fct>. a category i.

    3. To: <fct>. the gaining category in the transition of interest (n).

    4. Interval: <dbl>. duration of the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    5. T_i2n_km2/T_i2n_pixel: <dbl>. transition from category i to category n during time interval [Yt, Yt+1] where i is not equal to n.

    6. Rtin: <dbl>. annual intensity of transition from category i to category n during time interval [Yt, Yt+1] where i is not equal to n.

    7. Wtn: <dbl>. value of uniform intensity of transition to category n from all non-n categories at time Yt during time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

  • loss_m: An "IntensityL03" object containing a slot with lookup table af the colors associate with the land classes and a table with 7 columns:

    1. Period: <fct>. The period [Yt, Yt+1].

    2. To: <fct>. a category j.

    3. From: <fct>. the losing category in the transition of interest (m).

    4. Interval: <dbl>. duration of the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    5. T_m2j_km2/T_m2j_pixel: <dbl>. a transition from category m to category j during time interval [Yt, Yt+1] where j is not equal to m.

    6. Qtmj: <dbl>. annual intensity of transition from category m to category j during time interval [Yt, Yt+1] where j is not equal to m.

    7. Vtm: <dbl>. value of uniform intensity of transition from category m to all non-m categories at time Yt+1 during time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

  • st_lv2_gain: A tibble of stationarity test in level 02 gain containing 5 columns:

    1. To: <fct>. acategory j.

    2. gain: <int>. Number of time the class loss during time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

    3. N: <int>. Number total of time of trasition to be considered as stationary (T).

    4. Stationarity: <chr>. Active Gain or Dormant Gain.

    5. Test: <chr>. Y for stationarity detected and N when not.

  • st_lv2_loss: A tibble of stationarity test in level 02 loss containing 5 columns:

    1. From: <fct>. acategory i.

    2. loss: <int>. Number of time the class loss during time interval [Yt, Yt+1].

    3. N: <int>. Number total of time of trasition to be considered as stationary (T).

    4. Stationarity: <chr>. Active Loss or Dormant Loss.

    5. Test: <chr>. Y for stationarity detected and N when not.

  • st_gain_n: A tibble of stationarity test in level 03 gain on class n containing 5 columns:

    1. From: <fct>. the losing category in the transition of interest to the n category.

    2. loss: <int>. Number of time the class loss to the n class.

    3. N: <int>. Number total of time of trasition to be considered as stationary (T).

    4. Stationarity: <chr>. targeted by or avoided by by the n class.

    5. Test: <chr>. Y for stationarity detected and N when not.

  • st_loss_m: A tibble of stationarity test in level 03 loss on class m containing 5 columns:

    1. To: <fct>. the gaining category in the transition of interest from the m category.

    2. gain: <int>. Number of time the class gain from the m class.

    3. N: <int>. Number total of time of trasition to be considered as stationary (T).

    4. Stationarity: <chr>. targeted or avoided by the m class.

    5. Test: <chr>. Y for stationarity detected and N when not.

References

Aldwaik, S. Z. and Pontius, R. G. (2012) ‘Intensity analysis to unify measurements of size and stationarity of land changes by interval, category, and transition’, Landscape and Urban Planning. Elsevier B.V., 106(1), pp. 103–114. doi: 10.1016/j.landurbplan.2012.02.010 .

Aldwaik, S. Z. and Pontius, R. G. (2013) ‘Map errors that could account for deviations from a uniform intensity of land change’, International Journal of Geographical Information Science. Taylor & Francis, 27(9), pp. 1717–1739. doi: 10.1080/13658816.2013.787618 .

Examples

intensityanalysis(dataset = SL_2002_2014, class_n = "Ap", class_m = "SG", area_km2 = TRUE)
